     106              : // OPENSSL_DEPRECATED is used to mark a function as deprecated. Use
     107              : // of any functions so marked in caller code will produce a warning.
     108              : // OPENSSL_BEGIN_ALLOW_DEPRECATED and OPENSSL_END_ALLOW_DEPRECATED

     162              : #if defined(__GNUC__) || defined(__clang__)
     163              : #define OPENSSL_UNUSED __attribute__((unused))
     164              : #elif defined(_MSC_VER)
     165              : // __pragma wants to be on a separate line. The following is what it takes to
     166              : // stop clang-format from messing with that.
     167              : // clang-format off
     168              : #define OPENSSL_UNUSED __pragma(warning(suppress : 4505)) \
     169              : /* */
     170              : // clang-format on
     171              : #else
     172              : #define OPENSSL_UNUSED
     173              : #endif
     174              : 
     175              : // C and C++ handle inline functions differently. In C++, an inline function is
     176              : // defined in just the header file, potentially emitted in multiple compilation
     177              : // units (in cases the compiler did not inline), but each copy must be identical
     178              : // to satsify ODR. In C, a non-static inline must be manually emitted in exactly
     179              : // one compilation unit with a separate extern inline declaration.
     180              : //
     181              : // In both languages, exported inline functions referencing file-local symbols
     182              : // are problematic. C forbids this altogether (though GCC and Clang seem not to
     183              : // enforce it). It works in C++, but ODR requires the definitions be identical,
     184              : // including all names in the definitions resolving to the "same entity". In
     185              : // practice, this is unlikely to be a problem, but an inline function that
     186              : // returns a pointer to a file-local symbol
     187              : // could compile oddly.
     188              : //
     189              : // Historically, we used static inline in headers. However, to satisfy ODR, use
     190              : // plain inline in C++, to allow inline consumer functions to call our header
     191              : // functions. Plain inline would also work better with C99 inline, but that is
     192              : // not used much in practice, extern inline is tedious, and there are conflicts
     193              : // with the old gnu89 model:
     194              : // https://stackoverflow.com/questions/216510/extern-inline
     195              : #if defined(__cplusplus)
     196              : #define OPENSSL_INLINE inline
     197              : #else
     198              : // Add OPENSSL_UNUSED so that, should an inline function be emitted via macro
     199              : // (e.g. a |STACK_OF(T)| implementation) in a source file without tripping
     200              : // clang's -Wunused-function.
     201              : #define OPENSSL_INLINE static inline OPENSSL_UNUSED
     202              : #endif
     203              : 
     204              : #if defined(__cplusplus)
     205              : // enums can be predeclared, but only in C++ and only if given an explicit type.
     206              : // C doesn't support setting an explicit type for enums thus a #define is used
     207              : // to do this only for C++. However, the ABI type between C and C++ need to have
     208              : // equal sizes, which is confirmed in a unittest.
     209              : #define BORINGSSL_ENUM_INT : int
     210              : enum ssl_early_data_reason_t BORINGSSL_ENUM_INT;
     211              : enum ssl_encryption_level_t BORINGSSL_ENUM_INT;
     212              : enum ssl_private_key_result_t BORINGSSL_ENUM_INT;
     213              : enum ssl_renegotiate_mode_t BORINGSSL_ENUM_INT;

     218              : #else
     219              : #define BORINGSSL_ENUM_INT
     220              : #endif
     221              : 
     222              : // ossl_ssize_t is a signed type which is large enough to fit the size of any
     223              : // valid memory allocation. We prefer using |size_t|, but sometimes we need a
     224              : // signed type for OpenSSL API compatibility. This type can be used in such
     225              : // cases to avoid overflow.
     226              : //
     227              : // Not all |size_t| values fit in |ossl_ssize_t|, but all |size_t| values that

     370              : // BSSL_CHECK aborts if |condition| is not true.
     371              : #define BSSL_CHECK(condition) \
     372              :   do {                        \
     373              :     if (!(condition)) {       \
     374              :       abort();                \
     375              :     }                         \
     376              :   } while (0);
     377              : 
     378              : #if defined(__cplusplus)
     379              : }  // extern C
     380              : #elif !defined(BORINGSSL_NO_CXX)
     381              : #define BORINGSSL_NO_CXX
     382              : #endif
     383              : 
     384              : #if defined(BORINGSSL_PREFIX)
     385              : #define BSSL_NAMESPACE_BEGIN \
     386              :   namespace bssl {           \
     387              :   inline namespace BORINGSSL_PREFIX {
     388              : #define BSSL_NAMESPACE_END \
     389              :   }                        \
     390              :   }
     391              : #else
     392              : #define BSSL_NAMESPACE_BEGIN namespace bssl {
     393              : #define BSSL_NAMESPACE_END }
     394              : #endif
     395              : 
     396              : // MSVC doesn't set __cplusplus to 201103 to indicate C++11 support (see
     397              : // https://connect.microsoft.com/VisualStudio/feedback/details/763051/a-value-of-predefined-macro-cplusplus-is-still-199711l)
     398              : // so MSVC is just assumed to support C++11.
     399              : #if !defined(BORINGSSL_NO_CXX) && __cplusplus < 201103L && !defined(_MSC_VER)
     400              : #define BORINGSSL_NO_CXX
     401              : #endif
     402              : 
     403              : #if !defined(BORINGSSL_NO_CXX)
     404              : 
     405              : extern "C++" {
     406              : 
     407              : #include <memory>
     408              : 
     409              : // STLPort, used by some Android consumers, not have std::unique_ptr.
     410              : #if defined(_STLPORT_VERSION)

     412              : #endif
     413              : 
     414              : }  // extern C++
     415              : #endif  // !BORINGSSL_NO_CXX
     416              : 
     417              : #if defined(BORINGSSL_NO_CXX)
     418              : 
     419              : #define BORINGSSL_MAKE_DELETER(type, deleter)
     420              : #define BORINGSSL_MAKE_UP_REF(type, up_ref_func)
     421              : 
     422              : #else
     423              : 
     424              : extern "C++" {
     425              : 
     426              : BSSL_NAMESPACE_BEGIN
     427              : 
     428              : namespace internal {
     429              : 
     430              : // The Enable parameter is ignored and only exists so specializations can use
     431              : // SFINAE.
     432              : template <typename T, typename Enable = void>
     433              : struct DeleterImpl {};
     434              : 
     435              : struct Deleter {
     436              :   template <typename T>
     437            1 :   void operator()(T *ptr) {
     438              :     // Rather than specialize Deleter for each type, we specialize
     439              :     // DeleterImpl. This allows bssl::UniquePtr<T> to be used while only
     440              :     // including base.h as long as the destructor is not emitted. This matches
     441              :     // std::unique_ptr's behavior on forward-declared types.
     442              :     //
     443              :     // DeleterImpl itself is specialized in the corresponding module's header
     444              :     // and must be included to release an object. If not included, the compiler
     445              :     // will error that DeleterImpl<T> does not have a method Free.
     446            1 :     DeleterImpl<T>::Free(ptr);
     447            1 :   }
     448              : };
     449              : 
     450              : template <typename T, typename CleanupRet, void (*init)(T *),
     451              :           CleanupRet (*cleanup)(T *)>
     452              : class StackAllocated {
     453              :  public:
     454              :   StackAllocated() { init(&ctx_); }
     455              :   ~StackAllocated() { cleanup(&ctx_); }
     456              : 
     457              :   StackAllocated(const StackAllocated &) = delete;
     458              :   StackAllocated &operator=(const StackAllocated &) = delete;
     459              : 
     460              :   T *get() { return &ctx_; }
     461              :   const T *get() const { return &ctx_; }
     462              : 
     463              :   T *operator->() { return &ctx_; }
     464              :   const T *operator->() const { return &ctx_; }
     465              : 
     466              :   void Reset() {
     467              :     cleanup(&ctx_);
     468              :     init(&ctx_);
     469              :   }
     470              : 
     471              :  private:
     472              :   T ctx_;
     473              : };
     474              : 
     475              : template <typename T, typename CleanupRet, void (*init)(T *),
     476              :           CleanupRet (*cleanup)(T *), void (*move)(T *, T *)>
     477              : class StackAllocatedMovable {
     478              :  public:
     479              :   StackAllocatedMovable() { init(&ctx_); }
     480              :   ~StackAllocatedMovable() { cleanup(&ctx_); }
     481              : 
     482              :   StackAllocatedMovable(StackAllocatedMovable &&other) {
     483              :     init(&ctx_);
     484              :     move(&ctx_, &other.ctx_);
     485              :   }
     486              :   StackAllocatedMovable &operator=(StackAllocatedMovable &&other) {
     487              :     move(&ctx_, &other.ctx_);
     488              :     return *this;
     489              :   }
     490              : 
     491              :   T *get() { return &ctx_; }
     492              :   const T *get() const { return &ctx_; }
     493              : 
     494              :   T *operator->() { return &ctx_; }
     495              :   const T *operator->() const { return &ctx_; }
     496              : 
     497              :   void Reset() {
     498              :     cleanup(&ctx_);
     499              :     init(&ctx_);
     500              :   }
     501              : 
     502              :  private:
     503              :   T ctx_;
     504              : };
     505              : 
     506              : }  // namespace internal
     507              : 
     508              : #define BORINGSSL_MAKE_DELETER(type, deleter)     \
     509              :   namespace internal {                            \
     510              :   template <>                                     \
     511              :   struct DeleterImpl<type> {                      \
     512            1 :     static void Free(type *ptr) { deleter(ptr); } \
     513              :   };                                              \
     514              :   }
     515              : 
     516              : // Holds ownership of heap-allocated BoringSSL structures. Sample usage:
     517              : //   bssl::UniquePtr<RSA> rsa(RSA_new());
     518              : //   bssl::UniquePtr<BIO> bio(BIO_new(BIO_s_mem()));
     519              : template <typename T>
     520              : using UniquePtr = std::unique_ptr<T, internal::Deleter>;
     521              : 
     522              : #define BORINGSSL_MAKE_UP_REF(type, up_ref_func)             \
     523            0 :   inline UniquePtr<type> UpRef(type *v) {                    \
     524            0 :     if (v != nullptr) {                                      \
     525            0 :       up_ref_func(v);                                        \
     526            0 :     }                                                        \
     527            0 :     return UniquePtr<type>(v);                               \
     528            0 :   }                                                          \
     529              :                                                              \
     530            0 :   inline UniquePtr<type> UpRef(const UniquePtr<type> &ptr) { \
     531            0 :     return UpRef(ptr.get());                                 \
     532            0 :   }
